Comment: This is my first attempt at an annotation so any constructive criticism would be welcomed. I have enjoyed and benefited from other annotations and this is my attempt to return the favour. I am no expert on openenings and so will leave most of my comments until a little later on in the game

Removes the forking options, however white can still check with the bishop resulting in an exchange of knight and bishop for my rook and a pawn.

Still in the three knights game. I like this move as it either forces whites queen onto a black square restricting it's movement, or white can block the attack with his knight. If his knight doesn't move I can move the bishop to g5 to help defend the f7 pawn

Still in the three knights game. I like this move as it either forces whites queen onto a black square restricting it's movement, or white can block the attack with his knight. If his knight doesn't move I can move the bishop to g5 to help defend the f7 pawn

Now it's my turn to get aggressive. The knight seems well placed there  as it is difficult to remove, it also has an eye on f3.

At this point the Gameknot database has 2 games, one where black wins and one white, so I guess the game is evenl;y balanced, though I prefer blacks position, the white queen seems awkwardly placed to me and whites dsb isn't going anywhere fast

this allows me to move my bishop where I want it anyway, as it means if he takes the f7 pawn I win the exchange. This move weakens whites defence around his king and restricts the knights escape routes
